epidemiology: Common skin disorder affecting up to 85% of adolescents. Can persist into adulthood.

additional: Hormonal profile in resistant or severe cases

treatment_protocol: Mild: Topicals → Moderate: Add oral antibiotics → Severe/Nodulocystic: Isotretinoin

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting up to 20% of children and 3% of adults worldwide.
treatment_protocol: Emollients → Topical steroids for flares → Immunomodulators if refractory

epidemiology: Affects 2–3% of the population. Peaks in young adults and middle age.
treatment_protocol: Topicals for mild → Phototherapy/systemics for moderate/severe

epidemiology: Common in infants (cradle cap) and adults (especially males). Associated with Parkinson’s disease and HIV.
treatment_protocol: Mild shampoo → Antifungal + steroid creams → Maintain with antifungals

epidemiology: Superficial dermatophyte infection of body skin. Common in warm climates and close contact settings.
treatment_protocol: Topical antifungals 2–4 weeks → Oral if refractory/widespread

epidemiology: Very common. Two types: irritant (80%) and allergic. Affects all ages. Occupational hazard.
treatment_protocol: Identify trigger → Avoid exposure → Use topicals for inflammation

epidemiology: Affects 15–20% of the population at some point. Acute form most common.
treatment_protocol: Acute: Antihistamines → Severe: Add steroids or epinephrine as indicated

epidemiology: Common parasitic skin infestation. Highly contagious, affects all ages globally.
treatment_protocol: Permethrin cream 8–14 hours → Repeat in 1 week → Ivermectin for crusted/resistant

epidemiology: Uncommon, immune-mediated disorder. Affects middle-aged adults, often idiopathic.
treatment_protocol: Topical steroids → Systemics if widespread or mucosal

epidemiology: Common self-limited eruption. Mostly affects adolescents and young adults. Often seasonal.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Topicals if symptomatic → Resolves in 6–8 weeks

epidemiology: Acute hypersensitivity reaction often triggered by infections (HSV, Mycoplasma). Affects young adults.
treatment_protocol: Treat cause → Symptomatic relief → Monitor for SJS

epidemiology: Affects 0.5–2% of the population worldwide. Onset usually before age 20.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Phototherapy → Surgical grafting if stable and refractory

epidemiology: Most common skin cancer. More frequent in fair-skinned individuals over age 50.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy → Surgery or topical agents depending on size/location

epidemiology: Second most common skin cancer. Higher metastatic potential than BCC.

emergency_markers: Rapidly growing or deeply invasive lesion

additional: CT or MRI if invasion suspected

treatment_protocol: Biopsy → Surgical removal → Adjuvant therapy if indicated

epidemiology: Most deadly skin cancer. Increasing incidence globally. Early detection is key.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy → Surgical excision → Staging → Adjuvant therapy if advanced

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory facial disorder. More common in adults 30–50 years, especially women.
treatment_protocol: Avoid triggers → Topical agents → Oral antibiotics if needed

epidemiology: Common chronic inflammatory skin disorder affecting 3-5% of the population. Common in infancy and adulthood.

additional: Skin scrapings to rule out tinea

treatment_protocol: Topical antifungals → Add corticosteroids if inflammation → Maintenance therapy

epidemiology: Affects 15–20% of people. Two main types: irritant and allergic. Common occupational condition.

emergency_markers: Severe allergic reactions with systemic symptoms

treatment_protocol: Avoid irritants → Topical steroids → Systemics if extensive

epidemiology: Affects 2–3% globally. Chronic immune-mediated disorder with genetic predisposition.

timeline.symptom: Well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales

treatment_protocol: Topicals → Phototherapy → Systemics if severe or refractory

epidemiology: Rare autoimmune blistering disorder. Affects middle-aged and older adults. Higher in Mediterranean and Jewish populations.
treatment_protocol: Steroids + immunosuppressants → Monitor for remission

epidemiology: Superficial fungal infection (dermatophytosis) of the body. More common in warm, humid climates.
treatment_protocol: Topical antifungals → Oral agents if widespread or resistant

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting 0.5–1% of the population. Most common in middle-aged adults.

timeline.symptom: Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques

treatment_protocol: Topicals → Systemic steroids → Phototherapy if widespread

epidemiology: Common parasitic skin infestation caused by Sarcoptes scabiei. Highly contagious. Affects all ages globally.

timeline.symptom: Burrows in web spaces, wrists, genitals

treatment_protocol: Permethrin cream → Oral ivermectin if severe or crusted

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of individuals at some point. Can be acute (<6 weeks) or chronic (>6 weeks).
treatment_protocol: Antihistamines → Add steroids → Biologics for chronic refractory cases

epidemiology: Common self-limited skin disorder affecting mostly young adults. Thought to be viral in origin.

timeline.symptom: Secondary smaller lesions in 'Christmas tree' distribution

treatment.treatment_protocol: Observation → Symptomatic treatment → Spontaneous resolution in 6–8 weeks

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting apocrine gland areas. More common in women and smokers.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Antibiotics → Surgery or biologics if severe

epidemiology: Acute, immune-mediated condition often triggered by infections (HSV) or drugs. More common in young adults.

definitive: Treat underlying cause (e.g., antivirals for HSV)

treatment_protocol: Supportive care + antivirals for recurrent HSV → Hospitalization if severe

epidemiology: Affects 0.5–2% of the population worldwide. Can begin at any age; peak onset in 2nd and 3rd decades.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Phototherapy → Surgical repigmentation in selected cases

epidemiology: Most common skin cancer worldwide. Risk increases with age and UV exposure. Rarely metastasizes.
treatment_protocol: Surgical removal → Mohs surgery for high-risk sites

epidemiology: Second most common skin cancer. Can metastasize. Associated with UV exposure and immunosuppression.
treatment_protocol: Surgery → Mohs if in critical areas → Adjunctive radiotherapy if advanced

epidemiology: Most dangerous form of skin cancer. Increasing incidence worldwide. High metastatic potential.

timeline.symptom: Rapid change in size or color

treatment_protocol: Excision → Staging → Immunotherapy/targeted therapy for metastatic disease

epidemiology: Common inflammatory skin condition due to exposure to irritants or allergens. Affects all age groups.
treatment_protocol: Avoid trigger → Topical steroids → Systemic if widespread

epidemiology: Affects 3–5% of the population. Associated with Malassezia yeast. Common in infants and adults.
treatment_protocol: Antifungal shampoo → Add steroid cream for inflammation

epidemiology: Seen in up to 20% of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Can also be isolated.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Systemic antimalarials if persistent

epidemiology: Rare, autoimmune blistering disorder associated with celiac disease. More common in men.
treatment_protocol: Dapsone → Add gluten-free diet → Steroids if needed

epidemiology: Autoimmune blistering disorder primarily in elderly. Incidence increasing with age.
treatment_protocol: Topical steroids → Oral/systemic therapy if severe

epidemiology: Rare autoimmune blistering disorder, more common in middle-aged and elderly. Associated with high morbidity.

timeline.symptom: Painful erosions especially in the mouth

treatment_protocol: Systemic steroids → Add immunosuppressants → Biologic agents (rituximab) in severe cases

epidemiology: Common superficial fungal infection of the skin. Affects all age groups; more prevalent in warm climates.

timeline.symptom: Annular erythematous plaques with central clearing

treatment_protocol: Topical antifungals → Oral antifungals for widespread cases

epidemiology: Fungal infection of the scalp, most common in children. Spread via direct contact or fomites.
treatment_protocol: Oral antifungals for 4–6 weeks → Follow-up with mycological cure

epidemiology: Highly contagious parasitic infestation caused by Sarcoptes scabiei. Affects people of all ages worldwide.

timeline.symptom: Burrows in interdigital spaces, wrists, genitalia

treatment_protocol: Topical permethrin overnight → Repeat in 1 week → Add oral ivermectin if needed

epidemiology: Common, self-limiting rash, possibly viral. Most frequent in adolescents and young adults.

timeline.symptom: Secondary widespread eruption in ‘Christmas tree’ pattern

treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Resolves in 6–8 weeks

epidemiology: Affects about 1% of the global population. Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes.

timeline.symptom: Often starts on face, hands, and genitals

treatment_protocol: Topicals → Add phototherapy if widespread

epidemiology: Autoimmune condition causing patchy hair loss. Lifetime risk ~2%.

timeline.symptom: Sudden onset of round patches of hair loss

treatment_protocol: Steroids → Add minoxidil → Consider systemic immunosuppressants

epidemiology: Chronic, relapsing inflammatory disease of apocrine gland-bearing areas. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics → Add biologics if chronic → Surgery for advanced disease

epidemiology: Viral skin infection caused by poxvirus. Common in children, immunosuppressed, and sexually active adults.

timeline.symptom: Flesh-colored dome-shaped papules with central umbilication

treatment_protocol: Observe if few lesions → Treat if widespread or cosmetically concerning

epidemiology: Very common benign vascular growth. Increases with age.
treatment_protocol: Leave alone if asymptomatic → Elective removal for cosmetic reasons

epidemiology: Occurs in ~5% of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients. Can also occur independently.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Add antimalarials → Systemic therapy for refractory cases

epidemiology: Most common skin cancer. Strongly linked to chronic sun exposure.
treatment_protocol: Surgical excision → Mohs for high-risk sites → Topicals for superficial BCC

epidemiology: Second most common skin cancer. Can arise from actinic keratosis or chronic wounds.
treatment_protocol: Excision → Radiation if non-surgical → Systemic if metastatic

epidemiology: Most dangerous skin cancer. Accounts for ~75% of skin cancer deaths despite being less common.

timeline.symptom: Rapid change in size or symptoms

treatment_protocol: Excision → Stage → Add immunotherapy/targeted therapy as needed

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of people at some point. Chronic urticaria is more common in adults and women.
treatment_protocol: Antihistamines → Add steroids → Biologics for refractory

epidemiology: Strongly associated with celiac disease. Prevalence ~11.2 per 100,000 in Western countries.

timeline.symptom: Typically on elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp

treatment_protocol: Dapsone + gluten-free diet → Topicals for local relief

epidemiology: Self-limiting condition seen mostly in adolescents and young adults. Possible viral etiology (HHV-6/7).

timeline.symptom: Generalized secondary eruption in 'Christmas tree' pattern

treatment_protocol: Supportive → Topicals for symptomatic relief

epidemiology: Most common type of drug rash. Occurs in up to 2% of hospitalized patients.

timeline.symptom: Typically starts 5–14 days after drug initiation

complications: Progression to severe drug reactions (e.g., DRESS, SJS)

treatment_protocol: Withdraw drug → Antihistamines → Steroids if severe

epidemiology: Highly contagious mite infestation. Affects over 200 million people globally.

timeline.symptom: Burrows in web spaces, wrists, axillae

treatment_protocol: Topical permethrin → Oral ivermectin for severe/crusted

epidemiology: Common chronic inflammatory skin disorder. Associated with Malassezia yeast. Affects ~5% of population.

timeline.symptom: Greasy yellow scales on erythematous base
Common sites: scalp, nasolabial folds, eyebrows

additional: KOH prep to rule out fungal infection

treatment_protocol: Antifungal shampoo → Topical steroids for flare control

epidemiology: Viral infection (poxvirus), common in children and immunocompromised. Spread by direct contact.

timeline.symptom: Small, firm, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication

treatment_protocol: Observation → Destructive therapy for cosmetic/contagious cases

epidemiology: Hypersensitivity reaction to various triggers. Most common in women aged 20–40.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Identify and treat trigger

epidemiology: Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes. Affects 0.5–2% of population worldwide.
treatment_protocol: Topicals → Phototherapy → Surgical grafting in refractory

epidemiology: Superficial dermatophyte infection of the body. Common in warm, humid climates.

timeline.symptom: Annular, erythematous plaque with central clearing

treatment_protocol: Topicals → Add oral antifungals if widespread or resistant

epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting apocrine gland areas. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics → Add biologics → Surgery for severe/recurrent
